name: dare
content:
dare verb
(BE BRAVE/RUDE)
Add to word list
Add to word list
B2 [ I not continuous ] to be brave enough to do something difficult or dangerous, or to be rude or silly enough to do something that you have no right to do: I was going to ask if his dog was better, but I didn't dare in case she had died. [ + (to) infinitive ] Everyone in the office complains that he smells awful, but nobody dares (to) mention it to him. [ + infinitive without to ] I wouldn't dare have a party in my flat in case the neighbours complained. Dare you tell him the news? I don't dare think how much it's going to cost.UK I daren't think how much it's going to cost.UK Do you dare (to) tell him the news? I'd never dare (to) talk to my mother the way Brandon talks to his. [ + to infinitive ] He was under attack for daring to criticize the mayor. See also
daresay mainly UK
More examplesFewer examplesShe fixed the child with a stare of such disapproval he did not dare move.I didn't dare say anything for fear of offending him.I wouldn't dare say anything against him to his mother!I dare not let the children out of my sight in this park.He's a bit possessive about his CDs - I wouldn't dare ask to borrow them.

Grammar
DareDare is both a main verb and a semi-modal verb. …
Dare, need, ought to and used to (semi-modal verbs)Dare, need, ought to and used to are often called semi-modal because in some ways they are formed like modal verbs and in some ways they are like other main verbs. …

something you do because someone dares you to: He jumped in the river at twelve o'clock last night as (also US on/UK for) a dare.
